articles.title: About this site
articles.description: This is a demo website for Summer 2021. We can either use this site as a template for the actual final product or we can just keep this as reference code. Here's a graph from the Mario Kart Records TidyTuesday data.
articles.contents:
This is a graph of the number of world records each Mario Kart 64 player set over the years since its release in 1996.


Show code

australian <- drivers %>%
  filter(nation == "Australia")

driver_numrecords <- ggplot(australian, aes(x = year, y = records, group = player, col = player)) +
  geom_line() + geom_point()

driver_numrecords

articles.title: Logistic Regression
articles.description: This is the coolest thing I learned last week: logsitic regression and hmm... looks similar to the IRT modeling equation (SUS!!). This is also for me to practice inserting equations into text like you would in LaTeX and doing fun things with the text.
articles.contents:
Logistic regression is a type of generalized linear model (GLM) for response variables where MLR doesn’t do well at all as in data that looks like this.



Figure 1: Logistic regression example from SPSS Tutorials



GLMs have a two-stage modeling process:
Model the response variable using a probability distribution
Model the parameter of the distribution by using a collection of predictors and special form regression
The outcome should be a 2-level categorical variable Yi that takes the value 1 with probability pi and value 0 with probability 1-pi. The predictor variables are written as xk,i which is the value of variable k for observation i. For data that looks like the scatterplot above, we want to choose a transformation that makes sense a.k.a the logit transformation:
\(logit(p_i)=log_e(\frac{p_i}{1-p_i})\)
The reason for this is because a linear model \(y=b_0 + b_1x\), although easier to understand, does not accurately represent the relationship between \(x\) and \(Y_i\). We need a function of \(p_i\) that can be translated into \(y=b_0 + b_1x\) from the logit model and vice versa. Here is a graphic comparison of plotting \(p(Y=1)\) vs \(x\):



Figure 2: Graphic comparison between linear and logit models



Here’s the algebra for getting the equation of the logistic function:
\(f(p_i) = b_0 + b_1x\)
\(log(\frac{p_i}{1-p_i}) = b_0 + b_1x\)
\(\frac{p_i}{1-p_i} = e^{b_0 + b_1x}\)
\(\frac{1-p_i}{p_i} = e^{-(b_0 + b_1x)}\)
\(\frac{1}{p_i} - 1 = e^{-(b_0 + b_1x)}\)
\(\frac{1}{p_i} = e^{-(b_0 + b_1x)} + 1\)
\(p_i = \frac{1}{e^{-(b_0 + b_1x)} + 1}\)
